Nasogastric tube insertion (for feeding and medication) - verifying position and on-going management in adults (NG); Broomfield Hospital 05102A NG

data.text: Contents
Documentation of decision to place a nasogastric tube ............................................. 14

Appendix 2: Record of Nasogastric Feeding Tube Insertion ............................................. 31 Appendix 3: Enteral Feeding Checklist Chart – Basildon and Broomfield ......................... 33

Appendix 5: Nasogastric tube (NGT) position record chart – Southend ............................ 37 Appendix 6: Preliminary Equality Analysis ........................................................................ 39
Introduction

Enteral nutrition refers to a method where nutrition is given via a tube into the gastrointestinal tract. NG feeding is the most common method of providing artificial nutritional support for up to 6 weeks and is generally the first choice in the acute setting.

Enteral tube feeding should be considered in people who are malnourished or at risk of malnutrition that have a functioning accessible gastrointestinal tract and are unable to maintain health by adequate oral feeding. (NICE, 2006).

This policy refers to the insertion of a nasogastric tube, for the purpose of feeding and medication, verifying position and on-going management of nasogastric tubes. It is intended to provide guidance and set standards for clinicians. This policy has been produced by the Nutrition Support Team and a multi-disciplinary team of practitioners, and is based on National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) (2005) Patient Safety Alert - Reducing harm caused by misplaced nasogastric feeding tubes and alerts in (2011) and (2012). A misplaced NG tube remains on the never event list. Placement of fine or wide bore nasogastric tubes is the responsibility of a competently assessed clinician (nurse or doctor).
Scope

This is a trust wide policy which applies to all clinical staff who are involved in the direct care of patients with a Nasogastric tube, ensuring a co-ordinated and uniformed safe practice for the insertion and management of fine bore nasogastric tubes.
The purpose of this document is to:
safely and correctly place, a nasal gastric tube
understand staff roles and responsibilities
expand knowledge with regards to trouble shooting
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the post holder is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and
implementation of this document is available. They will delegate the full implementation of this document to the Medical Director.

Chief Nursing Officer, Directors of Nursing and Medical Director – responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate this policy in all adult clinical areas. This includes ensuring that the Trust provides / supports the training required for staff to undertake the task and that there is appropriate competency framework to support this where required.
Deputy Director of Nursing and Midwifery and Clinical Directors will ensure that all staff within their Division are aware of and comply with these guidelines.
Nutrition Nurse Specialist will ensure that procedures are evidence based and follow national safety / clinical guidance, and provide competency training for appropriate staff
Associate Director of Nursing / Matrons / Senior Sisters are responsible for the implementation of this document at ward level.

Medical Staff and Registered Nursing Staff should be aware of and comply with this document. Senior Ward Sisters are responsible for assessing the competence and maintaining competence records of Registered Nurses within their managed areas.

Competency Assessment - Healthcare professionals (nurses and doctors) should ensure that if involved with nasogastric tube placement or position checks they have been assessed as competent through theoretical and practical training (NPSA 2011).

Nursing Staff - for nurses this consists of a one hour theory presentation by a suitably trained and competent practitioner and completion of a competency framework (appendix 1). This is also provided as part of the Foundation Programme for newly Registered Nurses. Nurses can complete their competency assessment in 2 parts. The initial competency allows the nurse check position of the feeding tube using graded pH paper and to administer food, fluids and medicines via a feeding tube. The second part assesses competency of placement of nasogastric feeding tubes.

Students - The role of a student nurse/midwife is to learn how to competently and safely perform nasogastric tube insertion, and the subsequent care and management of the patient. The student must always act under the supervision and guidance of the registered nurse, who is responsible for assessing student competence and determining the level of supervision
required: either direct or non-direct. Accountability for patient care must always remain with the registered nurse.
4.9.1  Within this framework of supervision, student nurses/ midwives are expected to be involved in all the aspects of care regarding nasogastric tubes.
Medical Staff
Only medical staff with evidence of competency can place nasogastric tubes or verify tube position on X-ray. Previous evidence of competency can be produced as necessary.

4.10.1 Medical staff must ensure that x-ray request form states that the purpose of the x-ray is to identify the position of a nasogastric feeding tube, and reason for the x-ray, i.e. aspirate not obtained or pH level not between 1- 5.5.

4.10.2 X-ray checking procedures must be timely and carried out by clinicians assessed as competent to do so. All results should be confirmed and recorded in a the patient record ensuring the most current x-ray for the correct patient is reviewed, the four criteria for confirming gastric placement and clear instructions as to actions required are documented using a structured approach and communicated to the relevant nursing staff (NPSA 2011,2016).
Foundation Trainees

Placement of nasogastric feeding tubes by Foundation Trainees is not a requirement of their training, however Theory Training Sessions will be offered to FY1 and FY2 Trainees during their placement here.
Core trainees
Will have access to Theory Training if not previously evidenced. In addition, they will require evidence of passing an eLearning modules designed to enable them to verify nasogastric tube position.
Higher trainees
Will be offered training as per requirements of their specialty.
4.13.1  Practical assessment of nasogastric tube placement will be assessed using DOPs (Direct Observation of Procedural Skills) by any Competent Assessor, usually Band 6 Nurse Assessor or above.
Wards where nasogastric tube feeding can occur

To maintain patient safety, reduce risks and the give highest possible clinical care, patients receiving nasogastric tube feeding must be managed on wards where identified registered nurses have undergone competency training and where there are sufficient numbers of nurses competent to safely manage the patients on each shift.

table_items.text: 70% of registered nurses on a ward
This will ensure that patients can be managed safely, feed, fluids and medication can be given and tube position checked
Tube placement can be achieved by using competent staff from other areas
The ward must have at least 2 registered nurses Band 6 or above who are designated NG Competency Assessors
Competency training is given as part of the Preceptorship newly registered nursing programme, nurses must be competent at the end of the course

data.text: Placement of fine / wide bore nasogastric tubes
NG tubes must be fully radio-opaque with external visible markings to enable accurate measurement, identification and documentation of their position.
Feeding tube pH indicator strips must be CE marked for gastric aspirate. Current supplier: - GBUK Enteral Ltd

It is recommended that a fine bore tube be used for nasogastric feeding. This is to reduce the risk of mechanical complications and for the comfort of the patient.  Only  Trust  approved  tubes  can  be  placed.  NPSA   ref  no NHS/PSA/W/2013/001.
Fine bore tubes have a guide-wire to enable easy insertion, but there are risks associated with the insertion of fine bore tubes, which include accidental tracheal or bronchial intubation.

Wide bore tubes can be used for feeding as long as they are a) radio-opaque throughout their length and b) have visible external cm markings. In Critical Care settings wide bore tubes should be exchanged for fine bore tubes as soon as practically / clinically possible, and before transfer to general wards (NPSA 2011).
Enteral feeding ports cannot be connected to IV syringes, or end connectors that can be connected to IV or other parenteral lines.

Before attempting fine or wide bore nasogastric tube insertion the healthcare professional must have been assessed as competent, having undergone assessment and supervised practice and adhere to the guidance within this policy.

Bronchial intubation is usually, but not always, characterised by the patient coughing (if they have a cough reflex). If coughing occurs, withdraw the tube and allow the patient to stop coughing before re-trying. Patients with no cough
reflex, or those with fluctuating conscious levels, would not cough and therefore caution should be taken when placing nasogastric tubes.
Explanation of Actions and Rationale

table_items.text: Check the patient's ID and explain the procedure to the patient
To gain patients consent and co-operation
Agree on a hand signal with the patient they feel the procedure needs to stop i.e. raising of the hand
To reduce the patient's anxiety by participation
Assist the patient into an upright position (bed or chair), ensuring their head is well- supported by pillows
To allow easier passage of the tube, whilst preventing the epiglottis obstructing the oesophagus.
If the patient is unconscious or semi-conscious, it may be preferable to lay them on their side.
To allow easier passage of the tube
Assemble the equipment on a tray and wash and dry hands
To maintain adequate infection control standards
Measure the required NG tube insertion length using the NEX measurement (Figure 1) and add an additional 5-10 cm to establish required NG tube length (1)
To enable accurate documentation of position (1) https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2503962
Check the patients nostrils are clear and clean nostril if required, If the patient is unconscious or semi- conscious, clean mouth and nose and suction if appropriate
To allow easier passage of the tube

Gloves and an apron. If patient is conscious and has a gag reflex use nasal spray with 4 to 10% lidocaine (i.e. Xylocaine pump spray 10%). Southend only Ask patients to occlude one nostril and sniff, first on one side and then on the other. Slowly spray the chosen nostril twice, spraying the anterior nostril and waiting 30 sec to 1 min before introducing more local anaesthetic into the nostril. Southend only Lubricate the outside of the NG tube with water

Infection Prevention To make procedure more comfortable for the patient. Anaesthesia occurs within 1-5 min, lasts for 10-15 min. Southend only To determine if one side is more patent and therefore a better choice for an initial insertion attempt To allow easier passage of the tube

Flex the patient's head slightly forward to reduce the risk of tracheal intubation. Insert the tube into the nostril along the floor of the nose. If any obstruction is felt, withdraw a little and retry.
To aid the tube along the natural anatomy of the nose
As the tube passes down into the nasopharynx ask the patient to swallow. If the patient is able to sip, water via a straw aids the easy passage of the tube into the stomach.
A swallow will enable the glottis to close and the tube to enter the oesophagus

Advance the tube to the desired length as previously marked. Do not remove the guidewire until the position of the tube has been confirmed. DO NOT FLUSH the tube before gastric placement has been confirmed.

To confirm placement in the stomach, gently aspirate (using the 60ml syringe) > 1ml of gastric fluid. pH 5 and below is safe to feed. If pH is between 5 and 5.5 a check is required by a second competent person.

Stomach acid of below 5.5 confirms correct position. Small syringes have insufficient draw. Note: If patient is on PPI, pH reading may be above 5.5 but still in the correct position. therefore a second competent verifier- must check the tube position. It may be necessary for an x-ray to be undertaken.

If unable to aspirate, use the tips described in Figure 2 Section 5.10 or on the Enteral leaflet that comes with the Enteral NG Tubes. Document procedure on NG Tube Safety form (Appendix 1) If still unable to gain aspirate, an X- ray is required Document X-ray result on NG Tube Safety form (Appendix 1) Once position is confirmed, secure the tube to the side of the face appropriate dressing
To comply with governance Auscultation is NOT a reliable method of
Ascertaining the correct position of the tube. To comply with governance To reduce the risk of necrosis to the nostril

In order to remove the guidewire, flush the tube with 60ml of water, then gently rotate the guidewire and withdraw. The competent health care professional who has completed the NG insertion must complete all relevant documentation in the care plan and complete a Nasogastric Tube (NGT) Position Record Chart for nurses (see Appendix 3 Basildon and Broomfield Appendix 4 Southend)

data.text: If safe to do so, ask the patient to drink some water or recognisable fluid and then try to aspirate again. DO NOT allow any patient with a swallowing difficulty to drink.
If the above actions are taken and an aspirate is still not obtained, then remove the nasogastric tube and begin the insertion process again.
Attempt the process a maximum of three times.
pH above 5.5

In some situations, such as when patients are fed continuously, when they are treated with acid-reducing medication, and when medications are frequently given down nasogastric tubes, it may not be possible to obtain aspirate with a pH between 1 and 5.5 and daily X-rays are not practical or safe.

Therefore, in circumstances where the initial placement was appropriately confirmed, and there is no reason to suspect displacement since (i.e. no vomiting, retching or coughing spasms and no unexplained respiratory symptoms) the only practical method of determining if the tube remains correctly placed prior to each administration of medications or feed may be through external observation of the tube.
Confirmation that the length of the external tube remains identical to that recorded initially.
Check that the NG tube is not coiled in the patients' mouth.
If aspirate is available, check colour and volume to assess whether gastric in nature
Fixation tape or plasters have not moved or become loose at any time.
If the patient is on acid reducing medication, aspirate when the level of drug is at its lowest.
Consider holding feed for one hour and re-aspirate.
If aspirate obtained but greater than 5.5 seek advice from a senior practitioner or second competent person.
If there is any indication that the length has changed, appropriate action should be taken to assess tube tip position prior to using the nasogastric tube.

If there is evidence that the tube has become displaced, for whatever reason, then only checking the position at the nose would be inappropriate as it could be coiled in the back of the mouth, so in this circumstance second line testing through X-ray, or removal of the tube if seen to be coiled in the mouth, would be appropriate.
5.10.1  Tube length should be recorded 4 hourly onto the enteral feeding checklist chart /Long term Care Plan – Critical Care, High Dependency
If pH persistently above pH 5.5:
Aspirate when acid-suppressant medication levels at their lowest
Note colour and amount of aspirate, assess whether gastric in nature
Consider holding feed for one hour and re-aspirate, taking appropriate precautions in patients receiving insulin therapy
Ensure patient not coughing or vomiting and no respiratory distress or cyanosis.
Ensure tube has not moved, check previously recorded length
Seek advice of a senior practitioner, second competent person
Note decision to feed DAILY in patient's healthcare records.

Decisions about performing x-ray should be made on a case by case basis. X-ray only confirms the position of the tube is at the time the X-ray is performed A record of the tubes length at the nares, should be recorded on exit and re-entry to the ward.
5.11.1  Advice available from:-
Monday – Friday in usual working hours: Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust x3112 Nutrition Nurse Specialist Team.

Out of Hours Monday – Friday outside of usual working hours, this includes all weekends and Bank Holidays– Duty bleep holder or Hospital out of hours or Senior Nurse on Edith Cavell Ward (if available)
Monday to Friday: Broomfield Hospital x6146 & 4552 or bleep 2265/1710 Monday to Friday: Southend Hospital x5424

Any inadvertent misplacement of a naso-gastric tube with feed running should be escalated to Matron , Duty Sister or Associate/Deputy Director of Nursing as a matter of urgency, incident report and escalate to On-Call Manager, On-Call Executive as a Serious Incident.
Documentation of decision to place a nasogastric tube

Before a decision is made to insert a nasogastric tube, an assessment must be undertaken to identify if nasogastric feeding is appropriate for the patient, and the rationale for any decision must be recorded in the patient's healthcare records.

If there is any doubt surrounding mental capacity, a Mental Capacity Assessment (MCA2) must be completed for the purpose of the nasogastric tube placement. If a patient lacks the mental capacity to make an informed choice, there are potentially difficult ethical choices to be made. Each patient will be considered and assessed on their own merits within an MDT approach and the decision will be made based on the patient's best interests.

A decision must be made that balances the risks with the need to feed or administer medications. Patients who are comatose or semi-comatose, have swallowing dysfunction or recurrent retching or vomiting, have a higher risk of placement error or migration of the tube, whereas patients on antacid medication are more likely to have pH levels of 6 and above, making confirmation of tube position more difficult. Actions to reduce all identified risks and the rationale behind these actions should be documented prior to insertion of a nasogastric tube for the purpose of feeding, as follows:

The  details  of  the  assessment  must  be  recorded  in  the  patient's healthcare  records prior  to  commencement  of feed.  Including  any discussion had with the patient or next of kin / family.

The decision to insert a nasogastric tube for the purpose of feeding must be made following careful assessment of the risks and benefits by at least two competent health care professionals including the senior doctor responsible for the patient's care.

As a minimum, documentation should include signed, dated and timed entry, of the process of initial risk assessment that evaluates the benefits against the risks of introducing a nasogastric tube for the purpose of feeding. For example:

6.3.1 Nasogastric tube insertion can be dangerous as well as difficult in patients with altered anatomy, for example oesophageal fistula or pharyngeal pouch or in certain clinical conditions, such as basal skull fracture. In these situations, or if these are suspected, senior clinical help should be sought and nasogastric tube insertion should only be attempted under fluoroscopic control.

6.3.2 If a feeding tube is displaced and requires replacement, a risk assessment should be re-written into the healthcare records, as the risk for individual patients may change with time, especially if the feeding tube is regularly pulled out.
Indications for placement of Nasogastric tube

Placement of a nasogastric tube should occur when there is sufficient experienced support, knowledge or expertise, available to confirm nasogastric tube placement (NPSA 2011). This may mean delaying placement at night until that support is available.

Placement in clinically urgent cases is acceptable out of routine ‘working' hours if, following assessment; the benefits outweigh the risk of placement and verification of tube position. Rationales for either decision must be recorded into the healthcare records
Nasogastric tubes are placed for a variety of reasons. Most commonly:-
Administration of feed, fluids and medicines
Aspiration of gastric contents / Decompression of stomach Wide bore NGT only
Gastric lavage Wide bore NGT only
Also patients who:
Have neuromuscular swallowing difficulties
Have oesophageal problems
Have upper Gastrointestinal (GI) problems or gastric outlet obstruction
Are about to or have had oral/pharyngeal surgery or chemo/radiotherapy
Have had upper GI surgery
Have GI dysfunction or malabsorption
Require supplementary feeding to meet nutritional requirements
Are being weaned off Parenteral (intravenous) Nutrition (PN)
Contra-indications for placing a nasogastric tube
Non-functioning GI tract
Large gastric aspirate volumes
Intractable vomiting not resolved by anti-emetics
Nasal septum deviation
Basal skull fractures
Perforated oesophagus
Gastric outflow obstruction, unless for drainage
Facial trauma / fractures
Tracheo-oral fistula
Oesophageal pouch
CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) can be considered, with close observation for increased risk of reflux aspiration.
Choanal atresia (congenital narrowing of the nasal airway by tissue). This list is not exhaustive.

Cautions (to placement) – only competent experienced practitioners (e.g. Nutrition Nurse/ Specialists / Gastroenterologists) to place or use of alternate method of placement e.g. fluoroscopy , endoscopy and interventional radiology
Oesophageal / gastric varices
Coagulopathy
Oesophageal carcinoma
Gastrectomy or partial gastrectomy
Oesophageal stricture
Complications of nasogastric tube placement
Trauma, bleeding, perforation of oesophagus / stomach
Misplacement (bronchial, pleural, cranial, small intestine)
Accidental removal: risk of aspiration
Occlusion
Ulceration of nasal passages
Ear pain / otitis media
Tube blockage
If a blockage occurs within a nasogastric tube, do not force water into the tube as this could cause damage.

Using a 60ml syringe filled with warm water with half t-spoon of dissolved bicarbonate of soda and gently attempt a push/pull motion alternating drawing back on the plunger with flushing the tube. This is obtained from pharmacy

If the blockage persists, gently squeeze or massage the tube between your fingers from the nose to the end of the tube. You may need to remove the end (if removable) to allow for the blockage to pass through.
If the blockage occurs within normal working hours, please contact the CNS Nutrition for further advice.
Possible causes of a blocked NGT are:

table_items.text: Not flushing or inadequate flushing after feed and medication.
Flush with 60ml water before and after feed or medication.
Unsuitable medicine preparations for giving via an NGT, e.g. large particles, viscous liquids.
Review medication and consider alternative medication. All medication given via NG tube should be in either liquid or dissolvable form if possible. Liaise with pharmacist.
Multiple medications being given together without a flush in between each drug.
All medications should be given separately, flushing about 10ml of water in between each medication.

data.text: Kinked NGT  NGT may be kinked in the stomach, pull back
slightly (1-2cm) and confirm NGT position.
The new measurement confirming NGT Position including pH of gastric aspirate should be recorded and actions documented
Procedure for bedside placement of a nasogastric tube in an
adult patient
Equipment required:
Record of nasogastric feeding tube insertion.
Enteral feeding checklist chart
Critical Care/ High Dependency Nasogastric feeding tube care plan.
National & Trust approved nasogastric feeding tube
Gloves - non sterile / apron (PPE).
Sterile water as Basildon and Tap water applies to Broomfield and Southend
Recognisable oral drink (if appropriate) AND ONLY if able to drink.
Receiver or bowl,
60ml luer lock enteral syringe.
CE pH graded strips.
Tissues or wipes.
Clear film dressings/Grip Lock or Trust approved dressing to secure nasogastric feeding tube.
Topical Anaesthesia (currently applicable to Southend Hospital
only)-
Procedure

Gain verbal consent from patient, explaining all risks, benefits and the procedure. If appropriate, agree a hand signal with the patient by which they can communicate if the health care professional needs to stop, e.g. the raising of the hand.

Where an adult patient lacks capacity, a nasogastric tube may be placed if it is in their best interests as long as it has not been refused  in  advance  in  a  valid  and  applicable  advance  decision (previously called an advance directive).. See Consent Policy and MCA Policy

Assist the patient to an upright position ensuring their head and shoulders are well supported by pillows or seated in a chair. (If patient is unconscious or semiconscious, it may preferable to lay the patient on their side).
Assemble equipment onto a tray / dressing trolley and wash and dry hands.
Measure the length of tube required. Measure from nose, to earlobe to  xiphysternum  +  5-10  cm  (NEX  measurement,  see  diagram). Make a note of the length.
Ensure patency of nostrils, by asking patient to blow their nose or if semi or unconscious, performing mouth and nasal care may be necessary prior to passing tube.

Put on non-sterile gloves / apron, lubricate the outside of the tube by ‘dipping the tip' with Sterile -/ tap water as per manufacturers guidelines,  you  must  not  flush  the  tube  with  water  or  use  any artificial lubricants, prior to insertion and confirmation of position.
Insert  tube  into  the  nostril  along  the  floor  of  the  nose.   If  any obstruction is felt withdraw slightly and retry.
As the tube passes down into the naso-pharynx, ask the patient to swallow. If patient is unable to swallow on command, be patient and wait for swallow.
If the patient is able to drink a sip of water via a straw this aids passage of the tube. Use a recognisable drink e.g. blackcurrant, so that it can be verified on aspiration.
Advance the tube to the desired NEX length as previously measured.
Do not remove the guide-wire until the position has been confirmed.
To confirm placement in the stomach, gently aspirate >1ml of gastric fluid. Apply to pH graded strips. A pH of  and below indicates gastric placement. (See Section 5.1 for details)
A  mandatory second check of pH by a second competent practitioner is required for all initial placements.
See later in this document (Section 5. 5 .1) for information about
problems with obtaining an aspirate.
Once the position is confirmed, the guide-wire will need to be removed. The guide-wire can then be gently rotated and withdrawn from the tube.

It is essential that the tube is always flushed with Sterile water in BTUH or tap water in other sites, after obtaining gastric aspirate as if this remains in the tube it will lead to precipitation with feed or medication and can cause tube blockage.

Secure the tube horizontally to the patient's cheek with a small clear film dressing (or another type of tape e.g. Mefix, griplock), ensuring the measurement at the nares is clearly visible. The securing tape should be changed every 2-3 days or sooner if required. The external position of the tube should be changed slightly each time to prevent nasal pressure sores.
ONLY use a 60ml syringe to flush or aspirate a nasogastric feeding tube as smaller syringes apply a greater pressure to the tube, which can in turn perforate the tube.
The patient should only be fed in a head up position of at least .

When re-positioning the patient or manual handling during the course of undertaking personal hygiene, the feed should be stopped or placed on hold. Nasogastric tube tip position should be re-checked before re-commencing feed.

Document procedure in the healthcare records using the Record of nasogastric  tube  insertion  (Appendix   Basildon  and  Broomfield Appendix   Southend),  this  will  include  the  assessment  by  two competent  health  care  professionals  on  decision  to  place  each nasogastric  feeding  tube,  in  addition  to  the  first  and  second mandatory assessment of tube placement by competent healthcare professionals.  This  will  document  how  position  was  confirmed, length of tube inserted, type of tube used, pH of aspirate, aspirate volume and colour, consent, lot no. of the tube. The date of next planned change should be recorded onto the care plan. Instigate an Enteral  Feeding  Checklist  Chart   (Appendix   Basildon  and Broomfield Appendix 4 Southend)) or long term care plan Critical Care/ High Dependency.
Naso-gastric tube placement in Critical Care
The  decision  to  feed  via  a  nasogastric  feeding  tube  should  be recorded into the healthcare records, see Section 4.1.

In sedated ventilated patients the Anaesthetic Team may place the nasogastric tube under direct vision with laryngoscope, placing past the  naso-pharynx  due  to  the  patient's  inability  to  swallow  and ensure correct route of entry. All other steps apply as stated above.

For initial nasogastric tube placement for intensive care patients wide bore tubes should be selected to allow for ease of aspiration, to ensure gastric absorption or to facilitate gastric drainage. Wide bore tubes are 12fg and above, and should not be confused with ryles tubes which are used for gastric decompression

If the patient requires the nasogastric tube for longer than 10 days, the wide bore tube should be replaced with a fine bore tube to ensure  patent  comfort  and  prevent  nasal  erosion  as  long  as clinically relevant.

When taking an x-ray to assess nasogastric tube placement. All ECG monitoring leads should be removed and the external portion of the nasogastric feeding tube moved aside prior to performing chest x-rays on ITU patients to allow for clear visibility of the lung fields and invasive lines in situ.
X-ray requests must clearly state that the purpose of the x-ray is to establish the position of the nasogastric tube for the purpose of feeding (NPSA 2011)
The x-ray image should capture just below the diagram to allow visibility of the nasogastric tube within the stomach.

Documentation of the assessment, procedure and how placement was verified should be undertaken using the Record of nasogastric tube insertion (Appendix  Basildon and Broomfield Appendix 4 Southend),) into the healthcare records.
Confirmation of position
Initial placement and on-going test methods must only be carried out by competent trained practitioners. NPSA (2012) states that prior to place nasogastric tubes and verifying tip position:
9.4.1  Use in conjunction with the NPSA Decision Tree (2011) (see Appendix 4)
First line test method – graded pH indicator paper
pH testing is used as the first line test method (NPSA 2011), with a pH of 1 –
as the safe, acceptable range.
Guidewires should be left in situ at initial placement until position is verified.
Use one strip per test
Minimum volume of 1ml aspirate should be used for visual assessment.
Apply aspirate to all 3 regions of the pH indicator.
Read immediately.
Potential difficulties can arise with recordings between 5 and 6. It is therefore necessary that a second competent person should check any readings that fall within this range.

All pH tests and test results must be recorded on the Enteral feeding checklist chart (see Appendix 3 Basildon and Broomfield Appendix  Southend)), it is mandatory to record length at the nares, (i.e. length of tube in) pH, volume of aspirate and colour of aspirate obtained (or Long Term Critical Care/ High Dependency.
Second line test method – X-ray confirmation
X-ray is used only as a second line test when no aspirate can be obtained or when pH indicator has failed to confirm nasogastric tube position (NPSA 2011).
X-ray requests must clearly state that the purpose of the x-ray is to establish the position of the nasogastric tube for the purpose of feeding (NPSA 2011).
External wires / chest leads etc, should be moved away from the chest to prevent misinterpretation, if safe to do so.
X-ray must only be interpreted by someone assessed as competent to do so. This could be a Radiologist or a Doctor who has under- taken training using the eModule training tool available in iLearn.

The assessment of the x-ray must be recorded onto the record of nasogastric feeding tube insertion ((Appendix  Basildon and Broomfield Appendix 4 Southend),) on initial placement, or in to the healthcare records at other times.
9.6.1 The radiographer is responsible for:
Ensuring that the nasogastric tube can be clearly seen on the X-ray used to confirm tube position.
Adjusting the exposure if the X-ray to allow the nasogastric tube to be visible to the bottom of the film.
Ensuring the film is centred lower than a would normally be appropriate for a chest X-ray so that it shows the abdomen as far as possible below the diaphragm
Adjusting the X-ray film to show the bottom of both hemi- diaphragms in the midline (NPSA 2011).
9.6.2 Documentation of the X-ray should include:
Who authorised the X-ray.
Who confirmed the position of the nasogastric tube. This person must be evidenced as competent to do so.
Confirmation that the X-ray viewed was the most current X-ray for the correct patient.
The rationale for confirmation of position of the nasogastric tube i.e. how position was interpreted and clear instruction as to required action.
Checks should be clearly documented (see Appendix xx)
On-going test methods
This will be done by aspiration of gastric contents and the use of pH graded strips, as described previously (Section 5.1), and measurement of length at the nares.
The position of the nasogastric tube must be reassessed:
Before administering feed or drugs.
At least once per day during continuous feeding, preferably during the ‘rest period'
Following violent coughing or vomiting bouts.
Where there is doubt over tube placement.
After moving or handling the patient e.g. after physiotherapy or oropharyngeal suctioning, personal hygiene.
Additionally, the external length of the nasogastric tube should be documented every 4 hours onto the Enteral Feeding checklist OR Long term Care Plan – Critical Care/ High Dependency.

In Critical Care Units or where patients are receiving continuous enteral feeding (24hour feeding), using pH to verify position may be difficult. In these situations a clinical evaluation and measurement of length at the nares should be carried out to help assess nasogastric tube position. This may include a visual check by a medical practitioner, using a laryngoscope or a chest x-ray where there is doubt about placement. It is acceptable for a medical practitioner to document into the healthcare records, following assessment using their clinical judgement, the intended use of a nasogastric tube in the absence of a pH recording, if other checks
confirm tube position.
Unacceptable methods

Determining the position of nasogastric feeding tubes by auscultation of air into the stomach (Whoosh test) is an unreliable method of checking nasogastric tube position, and is not a recognised method of tube position verification in this Trust (NPSA 2005). Auscultation is where the practitioner uses a syringe to push air into the stomach, whilst listening over the stomach with a stethoscope.
Litmus paper must not be used.
Perforated nasogastric feeding tube

Fine bore feeding tubes can become easily blocked, if force is used to try to unblock the tube there is a risk that the tube can perforate. As a general rule, ONLY use a 60ml syringe to administer fluid and medication. Where a smaller dose of medication is required, use a smaller syringe only after ensuring nasogastric tube patency with a 60ml syringe. Perforated nasogastric feeding tubes are not easy to identify, but suspected if feed is aspirated on suctioning oropharynx, unable to obtain a pH < 5.5, or air heard escaping from the tube (oesophageal belching), on installation of air. Regular flushing of nasogastric
feeding tubes and following pharmacists' advice on the administering of medicines are the most important actions to prevent tube blockage.
Trouble shooting
No aspirate
If unable to obtain any nasogastric tube aspirate follow the steps outlined.

DO NOT remove guide wire from the nasogastric tube until position verified (initial placement only) This is so no one feeds accidentally via the NG Tube before confirmation that it is in the right place
Move tube, advance or withdraw  – 10cm, and attempt to re- aspirate (on initial placement only if guidewire is still in position- naso-gastric tube must not be advanced without a guidewire)
Place 20-200mls of air down the nasogastric tube prior to attempting aspirate, to clear the tube of any debris or move the distal tip away from the wall of the stomach. Attempt again to aspirate.
Change the patient's position to move the fluid level in the stomach by placing the patient on their left side where possible (see figures 1
– 4). Leave the patient in this position for up to one hour if required. Attempt again to aspirate. It may not be position or practicable to move patients in the critical care environment.
Medication

If it is necessary to give medication through the tube, it is preferable to use either soluble preparations or an elixir. The tube should always be flushed with 60ml of water before and after any medication. (Refer to NMG 253 Guidelines for the administration of medicines to patients with swallowing difficulties.) Discussion with the pharmacist, will ensure medications are given correctly.
Considerations to be given to renal patients and fluid restricted patients
Oral Care

Oral care should be carried out regularly to ensure mouth and teeth remain clean and healthy, and to ensure patient's dignity and comfort. To reduce oral infections and subsequent chest infections from oral bacteria infiltrating the lungs.
Nasal Care
Secure the tube horizontally to the patient's cheek with a small clear film dressing (or another type of tape e.g.Grip lock Mefix), ensuring the
measurement at the nostril is clearly visible. The securing tape should be changed every 2-3 days or sooner if required.
The external position of the tube should be changed slightly each time to prevent nasal pressure sores
Flushing

The tube should be flushed before and after each feeding period or drug administration via the tube with a 60ml purple enteral single use syringe using freshly drawn tap water, (sterile water Basildon hospital, to reduce risk of legionella infection). The syringe should be discarded after every use, not left at the patient bedside.
All immune-compromised patients should have sterile water for flushing.
No smaller syringes should be used to avoid unnecessary force exerted on the Nasogastric tube. 60ml of water should be used unless otherwise stated on the patient's feeding regime.
Patient position during feed periods
The patient should always be fed in a head up position of at least 30°.
When repositioning the patient or manual handling during the course of personal care, the feed should be stopped or placed on hold.
Training requirements

Training is provided by the nutrition nurses in two stages: for accessing the nasogastric tube and administration of feed/medications: for insertion of nasogastric tubes. Staff will have attended formal practical training session and will have a competency assessment completed before they can either access or monitor a NG tube or undertake new tube placements
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Nasogastric tube compliance audits will be completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Nutrition and Hydration Steering Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Nutrition & Hydration Steering Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 6)
